@qiluo-msft you are right the design was that the file can be missing.

@bluecmd  can you take a look at this change. This is less exciting then your original change but work-around the issue that sonic slave docker got built with "make init" and "make reset". If you have better way of preventing it, please let me know or propose with another PR.

Hi!

While I can't say I noticed this behavior when I made the change, I found this passage in the Make docs that might be the reason why the include seems to cause other things to build:

> If an included makefile cannot be found in any of these directories, a warning message is generated, but it is not an immediately fatal error; processing of the makefile containing the include continues. Once it has finished reading makefiles, make will try to remake 
https://www.gnu.org/software/make/manual/html_node/Include.html

Reading that, it seems that this could possibly also be fixed by explicitly defining `rules/config.user` as an empty target that can't be made. Maybe like this (100% untested!):

```make

rules/config.user:

include rules/config
-include rules/config.user
```

Personally, I think the wildcard approach here is pretty smart and nice looking - but I also know we have `-include rules/config.user` in at least one other place, so defining this target once might fix it for everyone.

What do you say about giving this other way a try and see if it works and then we can see which approach seems the right way forward?
@bluecmd Thanks for digging up the information. The do-nothing target works with a slight tweak. The target needs at least 1 dummy operations to catch the rebuild. But it works! Thanks!

how do you differentiate if this is a pr build v.s. nightly build?

> how do you differentiate if this is a pr build v.s. nightly build?

For PR build, use the default variables, all variables, like dbg_image, swi_image, raw_image, etc, are the default value “no”. It is the old behavior, keep not changed. We can change options if needed.
For Official build, we do not override the setting, so use the variables defined in azure-pipelines-build.yml

Take broadcom as an example.
For Official build, the variables are as below:
```
- name: broadcom
  variables:
    dbg_image: yes
    swi_image: yes
    raw_image: yes
    sync_rpc_image: yes
platform_rpc: brcm
```

For PR build, the we do not set any variables:
```
- name: broadcom
  //variables: -- we do not set the variables here, so use the default variables.
```

Default variables:
```
  dbg_image: no
  swi_image: no
  raw_image: no
  sync_rpc_image: no
  platform_rpc: no
```

1.	I update PR 7369, @Stepan Blyshchak, can you check if it is accurate?
2.	Other than teamd netdev, are you aware of any other netdev is affected?
3.	Instead of disable the 99-default.link, is it the same effect if we set the macpolicy=none?

1. Thanks, it is accurate.
2. I was focued on team devices, but this can happen to phy port netdevs and this was observed by our team
3. Yes, according to what man pages say, although I find it safer to disable it completely to not have to worry about debian upsteam changes in 99-default.link. What do you think?

since /etc/systemd/network override /usr/lib/systemd/network, i think it is better to provide our own policy explicitly. we can provide a file with mac address policy as none and copy to /etc/systemd/network, it would be better since in the future we may want to customize the other policy as well.

> Thank you very much for looking into adding DPB for our platform! Everything looks great, I just have some comments.
> 
> I think it would be better to add a new HWSKU for the use case of a flex config. This way we don't have to change the existing HWSKU which may currently be used.

Ack! I can do that for sure. Sounds like a good idea.

> Additionally, the flex broadcom config can be put inside the platform folder instead of the hwsku folder.

Do you want me to switch over to `config.bcm.j2` as well as I see some other platforms are doing (referred to the "new" way instead of `sai.profile.j2`)?

> > Thank you very much for looking into adding DPB for our platform! Everything looks great, I just have some comments.
> > I think it would be better to add a new HWSKU for the use case of a flex config. This way we don't have to change the existing HWSKU which may currently be used.
> 
> Ack! I can do that for sure. Sounds like a good idea.
> 
> > Additionally, the flex broadcom config can be put inside the platform folder instead of the hwsku folder.
> 
> Do you want me to switch over to `config.bcm.j2` as well as I see some other platforms are doing (referred to the "new" way instead of `sai.profile.j2`)?

If that's the new way to do it then by all means. I think just renaming the file then changing sai.profile to point to the right file works. Although I'm not sure how this interacts with having the broadcom config in platform folder, since eventually the goal is to have every hwsku use the same unified flex-enabled config. You can keep the config.bcm.j2 inside the hwsku folder for now I suppose.

I have made the changes to introduce this as a new SKU called `Arista-7050-QX32-Flex` and set it as the default SKU as requested. I did this by copying the the existing SKU directory to the -Flex and moving my changes there instead. The diff in git sadly shows these as new files of course.

I will not include the `sai.profile` change here if that is alright with you, I thnk that might explode this PR a bit more than ideal.

> I have made the changes to introduce this as a new SKU called `Arista-7050-QX32-Flex` and set it as the default SKU as requested. I did this by copying the the existing SKU directory to the -Flex and moving my changes there instead. The diff in git sadly shows these as new files of course.
> 
> I will not include the `sai.profile` change here if that is alright with you, I thnk that might explode this PR a bit more than ideal.

- Just a comment, the consensus at Arista is to just have the DPB hwsku have the same name as the platform name. Unfortunately for the 7050QX32 this isn't possible, due to the name already being taken by the existing default hwsku. The motivation for not having a "-DPB" or "-Flex" is because DPB will be a standard feature across the platforms. No change necessary for your review though, down the line we'll think about renaming the hwskus for 7050QX32.
- Could you remove Arista-7050-QX32/hwsku.json for this review?
- Could you remove the change to "default_sku?"

The other diffs look good to me, thank you for the PR!

> Just a comment, the consensus at Arista is to just have the DPB hwsku have the same name as the platform name. Unfortunately for the 7050QX32 this isn't possible, due to the name already being taken by the existing default hwsku. The motivation for not having a "-DPB" or "-Flex" is because DPB will be a standard feature across the platforms. No change necessary for your review though, down the line we'll think about renaming the hwskus for 7050QX32.

Happy to be part of the discussion if possible, but I understand if this is an internal discussion held at Arista.
When you figure out what you want to do for the 7050 QX32 I can probably off-load those changes if you send me a description of how you want it done.

> Could you remove Arista-7050-QX32/hwsku.json for this review?

Yes definitely, that was left there by accident. Thanks for noticing!

> Could you remove the change to "default_sku?"

Ack. I thought it was a nice thing that new configurations would default to this new SKU, but I am happy to call the SKU opt-in for now. Probably want the LEDs stuff to be fixed before it should be the default I guess.

Requested changes are made, I will test the image a bit later today.

Thank you very much for looking into adding DPB for our platform! Everything looks great, I just have some comments.

I think it would be better to add a new HWSKU for the use case of a flex config. This way we don't have to change the existing HWSKU which may currently be used.

Additionally, the flex broadcom config can be put inside the platform folder instead of the hwsku folder.

i feel we need to name those docker properly

sonic-slave-buster -> amd64
sonic-slave-buster-arm64 -> emulated arm64 docker image that runs on amd64

for native arm64 image, I feel we should name the image as sonic-slave-buster instead of sonic-slave-buster-amd64. to align with
docker multi-arch document, https://docs.docker.com/docker-for-mac/multi-arch/, we should use manifest to differentiate sonic-slave-buster that runs on arm64, amd64, armhf. https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/commandline/manifest/

In the docker register, sonic-slave-buster will have three images, one for each platform, amd64/armhf/arm64. when user pull the image, it will pull the correct one based on the client machine arch.

as you know, we introduce this ENABLE_DOCKER_BASE_PULL to pull sonic-slave docker from ACR (azure container registery), and it looks like acr supports docker manifest. https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/container-registry/container-registry-image-formats which allow registries to store multi-architecture images under a single image:tag reference.

therefore, we should think our naming properly so that when user try to build arm64 natively, they can pull the proper sonic-slave container from acr.

here is docker manifest [example](https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/commandline/manifest/):

```
$ docker manifest create 45.55.81.106:5000/coolapp:v1 \
    45.55.81.106:5000/coolapp-ppc64le-linux:v1 \
    45.55.81.106:5000/coolapp-arm-linux:v1 \
    45.55.81.106:5000/coolapp-amd64-linux:v1 \
    45.55.81.106:5000/coolapp-amd64-windows:v1

Created manifest list 45.55.81.106:5000/coolapp:v1
```

to fulfill our goal above, we can replace coolapp to sonic-slave-buster.

then, we have following native images
sonic-slave-buster-amd64 for amd64
sonic-slave-buster-arm64 for arm64
sonic-slave-buster-armhf for armhf image.

we can rename current multiarch image to sonic-slave-buster-march-amd64-arm64. it means this is a multiarch image that emulate arm64 on amd64. since we might have a emulated image for armhf on arm64?

if we do not want to rename current multiarch image, then we will rename the native images to 
sonic-slave-buster-{amd64,arm64,armhf}-native

should we rename current multiarch image, or should we add native to new native arm64 image?

> as you know, we introduce this ENABLE_DOCKER_BASE_PULL to pull sonic-slave docker from ACR (azure container registery), and it looks like acr supports docker manifest. https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/container-registry/container-registry-image-formats which allow registries to store multi-architecture images under a single image:tag reference.
> 
> therefore, we should think our naming properly so that when user try to build arm64 natively, they can pull the proper sonic-slave container from acr.
> 
> here is docker manifest [example](https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/commandline/manifest/):
>

> $ docker manifest create 45.55.81.106:5000/coolapp:v1 \

>

>

> sonic-slave-buster-amd64 for amd64
> sonic-slave-buster-arm64 for arm64
> sonic-slave-buster-armhf for armhf image.
> 
> we can rename current multiarch image to sonic-slave-buster-march-amd64-arm64. it means this is a multiarch image that emulate arm64 on amd64. since we might have a emulated image for armhf on arm64?
> 
> if we do not want to rename current multiarch image, then we will rename the native images to
> sonic-slave-buster-{amd64,arm64,armhf}-native
> 
> should we rename current multiarch image, or should we add native to new native arm64 image?

Based on you comments and my research, I suggest to name the slave docker as follows:
1. Name the native image as sonic-slave-buster, which is same as current definition
2. Rename march image as sonic-slave-buster-march-{amd64,arm64,armhf}, or keep current name which is sonic-slave-buster-{amd64,arm64,armhf}. For the host arch is clearly when we do compile, there is not need to add host arch to the march image name. I think that add "march" to the name is more precise for understand. I'm not sure whether emulated compile can work on ARM server. When I start march docker by the CLI "docker run --rm --privileged multiarch/qemu-user-static --reset -p yes"(https://github.com/multiarch/qemu-user-static) on arm server, an error return with "standard_init_linux.go:211: exec user process caused "exec format error".  I don't know if the AWS vServer doesn't support it or the ARM server doesn't support it.
if you look at the example, the manifest name needs to be different from the image name, so if the manifest is sonic-slave-buster, then image name needs to be different.

comments.body: is there a behavior change when upgrade to 247 for the unified_cgroup_hierarchy? why is that we do not need pass this option prior to 247?

@lguohan  yes, there is a behaviour change in systemd v247 comparing to 241. Systemd comes now with cgroup v2 (unified hierarchy) by default. Current docker version does not work with cgroup v2 (comming in docker 20.10). To solve this without updating docker a unified_cgroup_hierarchy is set to 0 in kernel arguments.

comments.body: @sujinmkang , @jleveque , @Junchao-Mellanox can you please review this PR?.

To me, there are two issues in this solution:

1. thermals belonging to chassis does not have to be a ASIC thermal, they can be CPU sensors and so on.  We probably should not treat it as "ASIC overheat"
2. There could be thermal which does not support getting threshold, in that case, we might need provide a way to ignore such thermal.

> @Junchao-Mellanox
> Currently, we consider ASIC temperature only in system health daemon.
> If ASIC is not present/mentioned in ignore devices in platform specific config file, it won't even execute the current solution.

chassis.get_all_thermals() may return a list of thermal objects. And these thermal objects may or may not have threshold available, it is not so good to ignore them all by adding "asic" to the ignore devices.

@Junchao-Mellanox I agree that some thermal sensors may not have threshold value but here, we retrieve only the ASIC keys from the thermal sensors list and get the threshold for the respective ASIC sensor. Correct me if i understood anything.
